msgSnippet: Just write unit tests using junit to test objects in isolation.  Once you have many tests for all you separate functionality, then think about how to test

Just write unit tests using junit to test objects in isolation.  Once
you h=
ave many tests for all you separate functionality, then think about
how to =
test inside a application server.

Generally testing inside an application =
server is more difficult and
should not be your first goal for unit testing=
.

-----Original Message-----
From: Alagusundaram Paulraj [mailto:apaulra@q=
west.com]
Sent: 06 September 2001 20:48
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: =
Re: [junit] Need help


Jason
      Thanks for detailed mail.In my project =
they have already test
cases for java programs.Our application have
4 layer=
s we are using weblogic.

I am struck up with environment setup on Jbuilder=
 to test with Junit in
weblogic server.

I am using Windows NT m/c



Jason=
 Rogers wrote:

> A.P.
>
> There is a lot of documentation and plenty of ex=
amples hanging around
that
> would give you a place to start.  Look at JUni=
t's tests for instance.
Look
> at the sample Money tests that are published=
 with JUnit.  Go to
junit.org,
> or the junit wiki, or the SourceForge site=
, etc.  I think it would be
a good
> idea for you to try learning what you =
can from the documentation and
> examples that already exist, then, when yo=
u have more specific
questions,
> ask the group.
>
> It isn't that we are u=
nwilling to answer questions, it's just that I
think
> most people expect t=
hat new comers will put forth some effort in
addressing
> the learning curv=
e.  Personaly, I don't expect you to make yourself
> completely versed in J=
Unit, I simply expect you to familiarize
yourself with
> the product enough=
 to be able to ask intelligent questions about it.
>
> Try to understand wh=
at an Assert is, what a TestCase is, what a
TestResult
> is, what a TestRun=
ner is...  These are the basics.  (Actually, you
could
> even skip TestResu=
lt for now.)  Then, if you have a class that you
already
> know you want to=
 write tests for (or you are doing test first design
and
> have an idea of =
the class you will be writing) tell us about it.  We
will
> then have a com=
mon language for describing how to write the tests --
JUnit's
> framework!
=
>
> I hope you don't take this email offensively.  I understand that it is
=
> sometimes overwhelming to learn a new product (JUnit), not to mention
a n=
ew
> paradigm (unit testing or testing in general).  I only hope to guide
y=
ou to
> some possible good starting places.
>
> -Jason
